<h2>4. Interactive Graphs</h2>
<p>
Based on our data and analysis, in this section we will provide some interactive graphs and explain the inference drawn from them which will further solifiy our output and goal.
</p>

<h4><b>4.1 Fat content variability</b></h4>
<p>
The visualizations below analyze the distribution and variability of fat content across different types of cheese. They provide an overview of key trends and highlight significant differences in fat composition between cheese categories.
</p>

<h5>4.1.1 Description:</h5>
<p>
These visualizations include:
</p>
<ul>
  <li><b>Histogram:</b> This graph presents the overall distribution of fat content across all cheese types, highlighting common fat percentages and clustering trends.</li>
  <li><b>Boxplot:</b> This plot illustrates the variability and range of fat content within individual cheese categories, identifying quartiles and potential outliers.</li>
</ul>

<h5>4.1.2 Insights:</h5>
<p>
The analysis reveals interesting patterns in cheese fat content:
</p>
<ul>
  <li>
    <b>Histogram:</b> The distribution of fat content shows a significant concentration between 30% and 50%, with a noticeable peak around 45%, suggesting that many cheese types have similar fat compositions.
  </li>
  <li>
    <b>Boxplot:</b> Certain cheese types, such as "semi-hard" and "soft, artisan," exhibit a wider range of fat percentages, while others, like "firm, artisan, blue-veined," demonstrate minimal variability, indicating consistent fat content.
  </li>
</ul>

<h5>4.1.3 Observations from the Graphs:</h5>
<ul>
  <li>
    <b>Distribution Trends:</b> The histogram shows that fat content is not evenly distributed; most cheese types cluster within a specific fat range.
  </li>
  <li>
    <b>Cheese Categories:</b> The boxplot provides insights into category-specific fat content trends, with some cheese types displaying higher variability due to production processes or milk sources.
  </li>
  <li>
    <b>Outlier Identification:</b> The boxplot effectively identifies outliers, which can be explored further to understand unique properties or deviations in certain cheese types.
  </li>
</ul>

<h5>4.1.4 How This Analysis Helps:</h5>
<p>
These visualizations provide valuable insights for:
</p>
<ul>
  <li>Cheese manufacturers aiming to standardize fat content across products.</li>
  <li>Nutritionists and dietitians recommending cheese types based on fat percentages.</li>
  <li>Researchers studying trends and variations in cheese production and composition.</li>
</ul>

  <p>The following visualizations aim to explore the distribution and variability of fat content across different cheese types.

<div id="fat-content-histogram-title" style="text-align: center; font-size: 18px; margin-bottom: 10px; font-weight: bold;">
  Interactive Histogram of Fat Content
</div>
<div id="fat-content-histogram"></div>
<script src="https://d3js.org/d3.v7.min.js"></script>
<script>
  // Histogram Script with Interactivity
  const fatData = [40, 50, 45, 52, 50, 12, 14, 55, 50, 45, 45, 34, 34, 34, 34, 34, 48, 33.5, 40, 45, 45, 45, 30, 46, 46, 30, 26, 8, 45, 30, 20, 54.23, 45, 25, 25, 34, 34, 34, 48, 40, 32, 43, 28.5, 22, 28, 25.22, 20, 25.5, 50, 45, 20, 43.3, 62, 50, 8, 70, 15, 39.6, 32.5, 45, 11, 45, 30, 30, 37, 54, 30, 31, 20, 43.3, 21, 50, 45, 60, 35, 25, 7, 45, 75, 40, 30, 40, 45, 27, 10, 45, 46, 50, 8, 45, 45, 20, 55, 48, 30, 26, 60, 22, 50, 45, 34.2, 45, 50, 45, 27, 50, 12, 45, 24, 45, 12, 33, 26, 28, 28, 45, 55, 40, 45, 45, 14, 5, 45, 45, 51, 14, 60, 40, 48, 15, 35, 28, 32, 38, 50, 45, 50, 26, 40, 25, 50, 27, 50, 49, 45, 30, 20, 48, 45, 45, 30, 50, 42, 48, 45, 48, 45, 34, 29.8, 50, 23, 45, 50, 45, 36, 40, 35, 50, 48, 35, 45, 27, 45, 40, 13, 50, 22, 31, 60, 12, 12, 50, 50, 45, 21, 45, 50, 37, 45, 30, 25.8, 25.4, 18.4, 26, 20.8, 50, 50, 28, 50, 60, 50, 25, 40, 50, 45, 45, 40, 50, 55, 50, 40, 45, 27, 27, 40, 45, 40, 72.7, 45, 45, 0, 30.5, 33, 18.3, 32.3, 45, 40.5, 45, 45, 60, 45, 30, 40, 45, 8, 45, 34.4, 45, 51, 48, 25, 17, 18.2, 14, 36, 48, 45, 7.8];

  const margin1 = {top: 30, right: 30, bottom: 50, left: 50},
        width1 = 600 - margin1.left - margin1.right,
        height1 = 400 - margin1.top - margin1.bottom;

  const svg1 = d3.select("#fat-content-histogram")
    .append("svg")
    .attr("width", width1 + margin1.left + margin1.right)
    .attr("height", height1 + margin1.top + margin1.bottom)
    .append("g")
    .attr("transform", `translate(${margin1.left},${margin1.top})`);

  const x1 = d3.scaleLinear().domain([d3.min(fatData), d3.max(fatData)]).range([0, width1]);
  svg1.append("g").attr("transform", `translate(0,${height1})`).call(d3.axisBottom(x1));

  const histogram = d3.histogram().value(d => d).domain(x1.domain()).thresholds(x1.ticks(20));
  const bins = histogram(fatData);

  const y1 = d3.scaleLinear().domain([0, d3.max(bins, d => d.length)]).range([height1, 0]);
  svg1.append("g").call(d3.axisLeft(y1));

  const tooltip1 = d3.select("#fat-content-histogram")
    .append("div")
    .style("opacity", 0)
    .style("position", "absolute")
    .style("background", "white")
    .style("border", "1px solid #ccc")
    .style("padding", "5px")
    .style("border-radius", "5px");

  svg1.selectAll("rect")
    .data(bins)
    .enter()
    .append("rect")
    .attr("x", d => x1(d.x0) + 1)
    .attr("y", d => y1(d.length))
    .attr("width", d => x1(d.x1) - x1(d.x0) - 1)
    .attr("height", d => height1 - y1(d.length))
    .style("fill", "#69b3a2")
    .on("mouseover", function(event, d) {
      tooltip1.style("opacity", 1)
        .html(`Range: ${d.x0.toFixed(1)} - ${d.x1.toFixed(1)}<br>Count: ${d.length}`)
        .style("left", (event.pageX + 10) + "px")
        .style("top", (event.pageY - 20) + "px");
      d3.select(this).style("fill", "#4CAF50");
    })
    .on("mouseout", function() {
      tooltip1.style("opacity", 0);
      d3.select(this).style("fill", "#69b3a2");
    });
</script>

  A noticeable spike around 45% indicates that many cheese types have a similar fat composition.</p>
</div>

<div id="fat-content-boxplot"></div>
<script src="https://d3js.org/d3.v7.min.js"></script>
<script>
  const cheeseData = [
  { type: "firm", fat: [45] },
  { type: "firm, artisan", fat: [31] },
  { type: "firm, artisan, blue-veined", fat: [34] },
  { type: "firm, artisan, brined", fat: [0] },
  { type: "fresh firm", fat: [20.8] },
  { type: "fresh firm, artisan", fat: [45,45] },
  { type: "fresh firm, soft-ripened", fat: [7] },
  { type: "fresh soft", fat: [25.22,45,46,24,12,40] },
  { type: "fresh soft, artisan", fat: [45,40,22,45,22,25.4,18.2,14] },
  { type: "fresh soft, hard, artisan", fat: [8] },
  { type: "fresh soft, soft-ripened", fat: [60] },
  { type: "fresh soft, whey", fat: [40] },
  { type: "hard", fat: [45,34,34,35,48,49,48,30,25,45,45,30.5,33,18.3,32.3,40,34.4] },
  { type: "hard, artisan", fat: [45,52,34,34,34,34,34,54.23,45,32,62,30,30,50,40,51,48,45,40,48,45,40,45,51,36,48] },
  { type: "hard, artisan, processed", fat: [7.8] },
  { type: "hard, processed", fat: [26] },
  { type: "hard, semi-hard", fat: [26] },
  { type: "hard, whey", fat: [30] },
  { type: "semi-firm, artisan", fat: [45,55] },
  { type: "semi-hard", fat: [40,14,40,46,46,20,15,39.6,32.5,25,34.2,48,50,45,50,30,17] },
  { type: "semi-hard, artisan", fat: [48,50,33,45,30,29.8,50,50,35,50,50,50,45,18.4,50,50,40,45,40.5,45,8] },
  { type: "semi-hard, artisan, smear-ripened", fat: [45,45] },
  { type: "semi-hard, blue-veined", fat: [8] },
  { type: "semi-hard, brined", fat: [45] },
  { type: "semi-hard, processed", fat: [50] },
  { type: "semi-hard, soft-ripened", fat: [55] },
  { type: "semi-soft", fat: [12,33.5,48,28,25.5,50,45,50,8,50,14,50,40,72.7,45,45] },
  { type: "semi-soft, artisan", fat: [25,45,11,40,45,20,45,45,28,5,40,23,40,45,25] },
  { type: "semi-soft, artisan, brined", fat: [50,45] },
  { type: "semi-soft, artisan, soft-ripened", fat: [26] },
  { type: "semi-soft, blue-veined", fat: [50,27] },
  { type: "semi-soft, brined", fat: [25,45] },
  { type: "semi-soft, firm", fat: [30] },
  { type: "semi-soft, processed", fat: [30,43,31,45] },
  { type: "semi-soft, smear-ripened", fat: [50,42] },
  { type: "semi-soft, soft-ripened", fat: [45,13,28] },
  { type: "semi-soft, whey", fat: [20,27,36] },
  { type: "soft", fat: [55,20,45,43.3,21,45,12,35,32,38,50,50,25,50,50,30,20,45,50,45] },
  { type: "soft, artisan", fat: [45,28.5,20,50,75,22,45,45,45,45,14,40,15,45,45,48,45,50,45,45,45,48] },
  { type: "soft, artisan, blue-veined", fat: [34,45,50] },
  { type: "soft, artisan, brined", fat: [45] },
  { type: "soft, artisan, smear-ripened", fat: [12] },
  { type: "soft, artisan, soft-ripened", fat: [10,27,28,45,35,12,27] },
  { type: "soft, blue-veined", fat: [43.3,30,37,54,60,60,37,40,60] },
  { type: "soft, brined", fat: [21,55] },
  { type: "soft, processed", fat: [60,45] },
  { type: "soft, semi-soft, artisan", fat: [50] },
  { type: "soft, semi-soft, soft-ripened", fat: [50] },
  { type: "soft, soft-ripened", fat: [70,30,30,60,26,28,27,27,26] },
  { type: "NA", fat: [25.8] }
];

  const boxData = cheeseData.map(d => {
    const sorted = d.fat.sort(d3.ascending);
    const q1 = d3.quantile(sorted, 0.25);
    const median = d3.quantile(sorted, 0.5);
    const q3 = d3.quantile(sorted, 0.75);
    const iqr = q3 - q1;
    const lowerFence = q1 - 1.5 * iqr;
    const upperFence = q3 + 1.5 * iqr;
    return {
      type: d.type,
      q1,
      median,
      q3,
      lowerFence,
      upperFence,
    };
  });

  const margin = { top: 30, right: 30, bottom: 100, left: 50 },
        width = 700 - margin.left - margin.right,
        height = 400 - margin.top - margin.bottom;

  const svg = d3.select("#fat-content-boxplot")
    .append("svg")
    .attr("width", width + margin.left + margin.right)
    .attr("height", height + margin.top + margin.bottom)
    .append("g")
    .attr("transform", `translate(${margin.left},${margin.top})`);

  const x = d3.scaleBand()
    .domain(boxData.map(d => d.type))
    .range([0, width])
    .padding(0.2);

  const y = d3.scaleLinear()
    .domain([0, d3.max(boxData, d => d.upperFence)])
    .range([height, 0]);

  svg.append("g")
    .attr("transform", `translate(0,${height})`)
    .call(d3.axisBottom(x))
    .selectAll("text")
    .attr("transform", "rotate(-45)")
    .style("text-anchor", "end");

  svg.append("g").call(d3.axisLeft(y));

  const tooltip = d3.select("#fat-content-boxplot")
    .append("div")
    .style("opacity", 0)
    .style("position", "absolute")
    .style("background", "white")
    .style("border", "1px solid #ccc")
    .style("padding", "5px")
    .style("border-radius", "5px");

  boxData.forEach(d => {
    const center = x(d.type) + x.bandwidth() / 2;

    // Vertical line (whisker)
    svg.append("line")
      .attr("x1", center)
      .attr("x2", center)
      .attr("y1", y(d.lowerFence))
      .attr("y2", y(d.upperFence))
      .style("stroke", "black");

    // Box
    svg.append("rect")
      .attr("x", x(d.type))
      .attr("y", y(d.q3))
      .attr("width", x.bandwidth())
      .attr("height", y(d.q1) - y(d.q3))
      .style("fill", "#69b3a2")
      .on("mouseover", function(event) {
        tooltip.style("opacity", 1)
          .html(`Type: ${d.type}<br>Q1: ${d.q1}<br>Median: ${d.median}<br>Q3: ${d.q3}`)
          .style("left", (event.pageX + 10) + "px")
          .style("top", (event.pageY - 20) + "px");
        d3.select(this).style("fill", "#4CAF50");
      })
      .on("mouseout", function() {
        tooltip.style("opacity", 0);
        d3.select(this).style("fill", "#69b3a2");
      });
  });

  // Title
  svg.append("text")
    .attr("x", width / 2)
    .attr("y", -10)
    .attr("text-anchor", "middle")
    .style("font-size", "16px")
    .style("font-family", "Arial")
    .text("Fat Content by Cheese Type");
</script>

<h4><b>4.2 Scatterplot Section</b></h4>
<p>
The scatterplot below visualizes the relationship between fat content (%) and calcium content (mg) for various types of cheese. The adjustments made during the data preprocessing phase, such as outlier removal and rescaling, enhance the interpretability and clarity of the visualization.
</p>

<h5>4.2.1 Description:</h5>
<p>
This scatterplot provides insights into how fat content correlates with calcium content across different types of cheese. The following elements are highlighted:
</p>
<ul>
  <li><b>X-Axis:</b> Represents the fat content (%) of the cheeses.</li>
  <li><b>Y-Axis:</b> Represents the calcium content (mg) of the cheeses.</li>
  <li><b>Data Points:</b> Each point corresponds to a specific cheese type, color-coded based on the milk source (e.g., cow, sheep).</li>
</ul>

<h5>4.2.2 Insights:</h5>
<p>
The graph reveals interesting patterns in the dataset:
</p>
<ul>
  <li>
    <b>Clustered Data:</b> The majority of cheeses have a calcium content concentrated between 400-600 mg, with a fat content range of 20% to 50%.
  </li>
  <li>
    <b>Outlier Management:</b> An extreme outlier with calcium content exceeding 1500 mg was removed to ensure a better scaling and clearer visualization of the remaining data.
  </li>
  <li>
    <b>Milk Source Trends:</b> Different milk sources (e.g., cow, sheep) show varying distributions of fat and calcium content, providing a basis for further analysis.
  </li>
</ul>

<h5>4.2.3 Observations from the Graphs:</h5>
<ul>
  <li>
    <b>Fat vs Calcium Content:</b> A positive correlation is noticeable within certain ranges, but significant variability exists, suggesting that other factors may influence calcium content.
  </li>
  <li>
    <b>Data Range:</b> The rescaled graph highlights trends among typical data points, with extreme values removed to avoid distortion.
  </li>
  <li>
    <b>Cheese Categories:</b> Specific cheese types or categories (based on milk type) may have unique fat and calcium distributions, visible through clustering in the scatterplot.
  </li>
</ul>

<h5>4.2.4 How This Analysis Helps:</h5>
<p>
This visualization provides valuable insights for cheese manufacturers, nutritionists, and researchers by:
</p>
<ul>
  <li>Identifying typical ranges of fat and calcium content across cheese types.</li>
  <li>Highlighting significant variability or outliers that warrant further investigation.</li>
  <li>Offering a basis for grouping or categorizing cheeses based on nutritional content.</li>
</ul>

  // Filtered scatterData to exclude outliers (calcium_content > 1500)
  const filteredData = scatterData.filter(d => d.calcium_content <= 1500);

  const marginScatter = { top: 40, right: 40, bottom: 60, left: 60 },
        widthScatter = 700 - marginScatter.left - marginScatter.right,
        heightScatter = 500 - marginScatter.top - marginScatter.bottom;

  const svgScatter = d3.select("#fat-vs-calcium-scatterplot")
    .append("svg")
    .attr("width", widthScatter + marginScatter.left + marginScatter.right)
    .attr("height", heightScatter + marginScatter.top + marginScatter.bottom)
    .append("g")
    .attr("transform", `translate(${marginScatter.left},${marginScatter.top})`);

  const xScatter = d3.scaleLinear()
    .domain([d3.min(filteredData, d => d.fat_content) - 5, d3.max(filteredData, d => d.fat_content) + 5])
    .range([0, widthScatter]);

  const yScatter = d3.scaleLinear()
    .domain([0, d3.max(filteredData, d => d.calcium_content) + 50])
    .range([heightScatter, 0]);

  const colorScatter = d3.scaleOrdinal()
    .domain(["cow", "sheep"])
    .range(["blue", "orange"]);

  svgScatter.append("g")
    .attr("transform", `translate(0,${heightScatter})`)
    .call(d3.axisBottom(xScatter))
    .append("text")
    .attr("x", widthScatter / 2)
    .attr("y", 40)
    .attr("text-anchor", "middle")
    .style("font-size", "14px")
    .style("fill", "black")
    .text("Fat Content (%)");

  svgScatter.append("g")
    .call(d3.axisLeft(yScatter))
    .append("text")
    .attr("x", -heightScatter / 2)
    .attr("y", -50)
    .attr("text-anchor", "middle")
    .attr("transform", "rotate(-90)")
    .style("font-size", "14px")
    .style("fill", "black")
    .text("Calcium Content (mg)");

  const tooltipScatter = d3.select("body")
    .append("div")
    .attr("id", "tooltip-scatter")
    .style("position", "absolute")
    .style("background", "white")
    .style("border", "1px solid #ccc")
    .style("padding", "5px")
    .style("border-radius", "5px")
    .style("opacity", 0);

  svgScatter.selectAll("circle")
    .data(filteredData)
    .enter()
    .append("circle")
    .attr("cx", d => xScatter(d.fat_content))
    .attr("cy", d => yScatter(d.calcium_content))
    .attr("r", 6)
    .style("fill", d => colorScatter(d.milk))
    .on("mouseover", function(event, d) {
      tooltipScatter.style("opacity", 1)
        .html(`Cheese: ${d.cheese}<br>Fat Content: ${d.fat_content}%<br>Calcium: ${d.calcium_content}mg<br>Milk Type: ${d.milk}`)
        .style("left", (event.pageX + 10) + "px")
        .style("top", (event.pageY - 20) + "px");
      d3.select(this).attr("r", 8);
    })
    .on("mouseout", function() {
      tooltipScatter.style("opacity", 0);
      d3.select(this).attr("r", 6);
    });

  svgScatter.append("text")
    .attr("x", widthScatter / 2)
    .attr("y", -10)
    .attr("text-anchor", "middle")
    .style("font-size", "16px")
    .style("font-family", "Arial")
    .text("Fat vs Calcium Content (Filtered)");
</script>

<h4><b>4.3 World Cheese Distribution Map</b></h4>
<p>
The interactive map below visualizes the global distribution of cheese types. Each circle represents a country, and the size of the circle is proportional to the number of cheese varieties produced in that country. The interactive tooltips provide additional details for each location, including the exact count of cheese varieties.
</p>

<h5>4.3.1 Description:</h5>
<p>
This map showcases the worldwide distribution of cheese production, with the following features:
</p>
<ul>
  <li><b>Base Map:</b> Displays the world map for spatial reference using OpenStreetMap tiles.</li>
  <li><b>Data Points:</b> Each circle represents a specific country, sized based on the number of cheese types produced.</li>
  <li><b>Interactive Tooltips:</b> Hovering over a circle reveals the country name and the exact number of cheeses produced.</li>
</ul>

<h5>4.3.2 Insights:</h5>
<p>
The map reveals interesting patterns in global cheese production:
</p>
<ul>
  <li><b>High Production Regions:</b> Countries like France and Italy are major cheese producers, reflected in the large circle sizes.</li>
  <li><b>Diversity Across Continents:</b> While Europe dominates cheese production, contributions from other regions like the Americas, Australia, and Asia are also visible.</li>
  <li><b>Clusters of Production:</b> Some countries have closely clustered points, indicating regions with rich cheese-making traditions.</li>
</ul>

<h5>4.3.3 Observations from the Map:</h5>
<ul>
  <li><b>France:</b> The largest producer in the dataset, with 54 varieties of cheese.</li>
  <li><b>Global Spread:</b> Countries from every continent contribute to cheese production, emphasizing its global appeal.</li>
  <li><b>Interactive Features:</b> The map's interactivity enables detailed exploration of cheese production by region.</li>
</ul>

<h5>4.3.4 How This Analysis Helps:</h5>
<p>
This map provides valuable insights for stakeholders in the cheese industry and researchers by:
</p>
<ul>
  <li>Highlighting key countries and regions leading in cheese production.</li>
  <li>Enabling comparative analysis between countries and continents.</li>
  <li>Offering a visual tool for marketing and export strategy development for cheese manufacturers.</li>
</ul>

    { "country": "France", "n": 54, "lat": 46.1669, "long": 3.227 },
    { "country": "United States", "n": 15, "lat": 37.0902, "long": -95.7129 },
    { "country": "Germany", "n": 10, "lat": 51.2046, "long": 10.4012 },
    { "country": "Brazil", "n": 1, "lat": -14.235, "long": -51.9253 }
    // Add more coordinates as needed
  ];

  // Initialize the map
  const map = L.map("cheese-distribution-map").setView([20, 0], 2); // Centered globally

  // Add OpenStreetMap tiles
  L.tileLayer("https://{s}.tile.openstreetmap.org/{z}/{x}/{y}.png", {
    attribution: '&copy; <a href="https://www.openstreetmap.org/copyright">OpenStreetMap</a> contributors'
  }).addTo(map);

  // Add cheese data as circle markers
  cheeseCoords.forEach(d => {
    if (d.lat && d.long) {
      L.circleMarker([d.lat, d.long], {
        radius: Math.sqrt(d.n) * 5, // Scale size by cheese count
        color: "blue",
        fillColor: "blue",
        fillOpacity: 0.6
      })
        .bindPopup(`<strong>${d.country}</strong><br>Number of Cheeses: ${d.n}`)
        .addTo(map);
    }
  });
</script>


<p>
Here we leveraged powerful visualization libraries like D3.js and Leaflet.js to create interactive and dynamic representations of cheese data. D3.js was utilized for crafting scatterplots, histograms, and boxplots, enabling precise and customizable visualizations of complex relationships within the dataset. Leaflet.js was integrated to produce a geo-visualization, mapping global cheese distribution in an interactive and engaging manner, enriched with tooltips for detailed exploration. Together, these tools enhanced our ability to analyze trends, uncover insights, and present the data in an intuitive, visually appealing format, making the findings accessible and impactful for a diverse audience.
</p>
